subject: A Pox on Both Your Houses
event:
Regular readers of this Not A Blog will know what a fanatic fan of the NFL I am.

I cannot possibly express how disgusted and pissed off I am by the failure of the NFL owners and players to reach an agreement, which has now led to a lockout and may possibly imperil the 2011 season.  There are no good guys in this scenario.  It is millionaires versus billionaires, and it's all about greed, greed, greed.  

Don't believe what Gordon Gekko told you. Greed is not good.  Greed sucks.

When the pie is as big and rich and gooey as the NFL's, the inability of the principals to come to any agreement about how to slice it up is just obscene.  

Locking out the players?  Owners, shame on you.

Decertifying as a union so you can sue?  Players, shame on you.

The last bit is ESPECIALLY offensive in the light of what is happening in places like Wisconsin, Indiana, and Ohio, where real working class people are fighting desperately to keep their unions in the face of a concerted effort by the Radical Right to strip them of their right to collective bargaining.  The teachers in those states are battling for their pensions, their health care, and salaries in the mid five figures, while NFL players decertify to make certain their seven figure salaries don't get trimmed down to six.

Here's a proposal for you: the legislatures in every state with an NFL franchise should pass a new tax.  For every game missed due to a strike or lockout, the franchise owners should be required to take all the money they would have paid the players, and pay it instead into a pool to fund teacher salaries, benefits, and pensions.

Oh, to be the king.  Oh, to have some dragons.

comments.article:
I agree with you. Especially about how offensive it is that it is happening concurrently with real fights for union rights.

I like your solution (both the tax and the dragons)
A part of me just died inside.

Here's a proposal for you: the legislatures in every state with an NFL franchise should pass a new tax. For every game missed due to a strike or lockout, the franchise owners should be required to take all the money they would have paid the players, and pay it instead into a pool to fund teacher salaries, benefits, and pensions.

I used to be a teacher. I'm not any more. I love you for this anyway.
I agree. Though I'm not (never ever will be) a teacher, I think this is brilliant.

I submit that this is a good thing. The NFL has become a league of crybaby millionaires restricted by stupid and arbitrarily enforced rules that hamper the spirit and play of what was once truly the Sport of Kings. Sure, there are a few outstanding players who are great. But there are way more criminals and addicts who play for the money and ruin the game.

Screw the NFL. I hope it doesnt come back, ever.

Honestly, I'd love to see federal and state laws mandating the sort of financial transparency the players have requested. Specifically, if as an owner of a professional sports franchise, you solicit or accept public subsidies for facilities, you essentially become a public enterprise, and owe those entities an appropriate share in stock equivalent of your franchise, with all the disclosure requirements that come with it.

I think that would make a lot of the shenanigans we see about moving franchises around and playing one city off against another a lot less common and would make the game(s) either very private or very public. Enough of this give-us-your-public-subsidies-but-we're-privately-held baloney - let's encourage the rest of the NFL to follow in Green Bay's footsteps.
@ebongreen: Excellent suggestion.

Down in Texas, teachers don't have the rights they're fighting to keep up in Wisconsin. Right to work my ass.

There's 100,000 teacher layoffs in the pipes, and it appears it might happen with a whimper, rather than a bang.

The NFL's drama is just surreal, given what's happening elsewhere.

Don't blame the players. The issue here is that the owners are walking away from a collective bargaining agreement that they signed because they think they should be making more profit. The players would be perfectly happy to keep playing under the current CBA and not have to decertify. The whole point of decertification is to allow the players to then sue the owners under anti-trust law, something they can't do so long as the union is certified. Further, the NFLPA still exists, except it's considered a trade association and not a collective bargaining unit until the players recertify. They're doing this so they can get after the owners because the owners are trying to crush the union!

I love your work and generally agree with your politics, George, but you're simply wrong on the why and how of decertification. As a lawyer and a strong union supporter, I hope you look into this and realize that you're simply not correct in what you're saying about the players union.

For a good discussion of the legal issues: http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2011/writers/michael_mccann/03/11/whatnext/index.html for how things are actually likely to play out.
comments.subject: Hey now.

comments.article:
It is a tactic, yes. A bogus tactic.

Either they are a union, or they're not. They can't be a union on Monday, a trade association on Tuesday, and a union again on Wednesday, depending on which is most to your advantage.

They're a union. They have the right to strike. They do not have the right to falsely claim they are not a union so they can sue.
comments.subject: Re: Hey now.
Re: Hey now.
Re: Hey now.
Re: Hey now.
Re: Hey now.
Re: Hey now.

comments.article:
The last bit is ESPECIALLY offensive in the light of what is happening in places like Wisconsin, Indiana, and Ohio, where real working class people are fighting desperately to keep their unions in the face of a concerted effort by the Radical Right to strip them of their right to collective bargaining.

Quoted for truth.

The well-fed does not know the pangs of hunger, indeed.

Yes, because the average NFL player is a millionaire. Except, not really. The median career lasts 2-3 years, and the base salary for those kids is under 1 million dollars. Good pay, sure, but pretending that every player is getting Albert Haynesworth money is simply inaccurate. Heck, most of them aren't getting Brady Poppinga money. The median NFL salary is 770k, which means that half of the players earn less than that. It's a lot of money, but if your career is 3 years long and you face serious physical damage for playing the sport, we're not talking anything nearly like the wealth of the billionaires who own the teams.

This attitude here is, of course, how the truly wealthy get us to divide ourselves and fight each other rather than fighting them.

For what it's worth, the players have some pretty legitimate beefs with what the owners are asking. The average NFL career is 3 years, but retired players don't get health insurance unless they're in the league for 5 years. Which, given the spate of really serious health issues retired players have to deal with (dementia and such) simply from playing, is a really big deal.

Now the owners want to extend the season solely to make more money, which would shorten the careers of some players while exposing them to greater health problems. I can understand why the players went with the nuclear option and de-certified the union so they could sue. It's legitimately life and death for them.

The salaries disgust me too, but it's helpful to think about it as a really big pie, and the players deserve their slice of it too. More so when their health is on the line.
comments.subject: Bad guys and worse guys

comments.upictitle: The Captain Of My Ship, The Master Of My Soul: Spider.
comments.article: Gracious, the average career is really only 3 years? There's something very wrong there.
comments.subject: Re: Bad guys and worse guys
Re: Bad guys and worse guys
Re: Bad guys and worse guys
Re: Bad guys and worse guys
Re: Bad guys and worse guys

Re: Bad guys and worse guys

comments.article: Rather than arguing about money, the PA should be beating the Traumatic Brain Injury drum, and loud. A ten-year career (if you're lucky) that leaves you shattered body and mind, uninsurable and with chronic conditions, is not reasonable. Not even for superstar-money, which most NFL players don't get. Arguing over where the money goes is a sideshow compared to player safety.

Personnally I think both the owners and the players are wrong. I do want to respond to your comment about the physical toll that the players experience. Playing football is like any other job. If the long term consequences are a problem find a different job. By the way doesn't the union provide long term disability/medical insurance. I find it difficult to believe that only the owners can provide a solution.
I admit I do not know how that is currently set up. But I would think that the owners do worry about it considering all of the rules they are enactiing that try to reduce head injuries.

I'm a Packers fan and as soon as they won Superbowl 45 I said it's only fitting that Green Bay wins the first and last Superbowls. Greed will get you nowhere NFL... just look at the MLB, they haven't been the same since their lockout.
You can always try to fill the football void with hockey.  A fast paced thoroughly tough sport.

Although I don't agree with your statements about the public unions, I fully support your statements about the sport. It is a shame that the sport has to suffer because the rich athletes and the rich owners can't play in the same sandbox.
comments.subject: politics vs sports

comments.article: I have to agree with other posters who have said that the players are much less culpable for this debacle than the owners. The problem is that the player's union has done a piss poor job of getting their message out to fans. What the owners are proposing with the added games and other issues rarely affects the superstar player with more money than they know what to do with - it's the majority of players, not the Peyton Mannings or Tom Brady's or other anomalies. Most of the players make a nice wage, but certainly if considered over the course of a lifetime - it's really not that much money, especially given the level of talent they must have AND the scores of residual health problems they face. Most of these guys are kids that hope to create a better life for themselves and their families - not to wipe their butts with hundred dollar bills. By adding additional games purely for greed, the owners are putting the players in even greater peril without changing the rules of insurance that really affects 90% of the player's body. I think the player's union has done a horrible job conveying that to the public. Oh and yeah - they aren't on strike, they are locked out. Big, huge difference. I am definitely rooting for the players in this one.

"When the pie is as big and rich and gooey as the NFL's, the inability of the principals to come to any agreement about how to slice it up is just obscene."

Well, as George W. Bush once said, "we've got to make the pie higher."

(No, I don't know what that means, either.)
Apparently harder to reach in the first place.
Here here!

Here's a proposal for you: the legislatures in every state with an NFL franchise should pass a new tax. For every game missed due to a strike or lockout, the franchise owners should be required to take all the money they would have paid the players, and pay it instead into a pool to fund teacher salaries, benefits, and pensions.

That would work everywhere but Green Bay, where the people of the city actually own the franchise.

The NFL pie is big enough to go around.  However, government workers who get pay and benefits greater than private sector workers, strike every 3 or 4 years, keep their jobs despite poorer and poorer performance of their pupils only because of tenure.  I have lost 4 weeks vacation, two separate health plans, and more...and I am not complaining.  These self-righteous "intellectuals" and their Obama funded mobs lost, thank God.  The bigger the government...the smaller the people.

You SHOULD be complaining about losing your health plans. We need single-payer health care, like every other first world nation.

American education is in trouble. However, we will not improve it by decreasing the pay of teachers and stripping them of benefits and the right to organize for better pay and working conditions. If anything, we should be raising teacher pay and giving them more support.

It was never really about the budget in Wisconsin, as the Repubs proved by stripping the bill of all its fiscal aspects. It was a cynical move to crush the unions. Here's hoping every one of those GOP senators will be recalled. The fight is not over yet.

comments.subject: Re: Sigh....
Re: Sigh....
Re: Sigh....

comments.article: I'm sorry, but it's ridiculous to compare these guys to policemen and firefighters. I appreciate the job that they do, but there's FAR fewer men who can be professional caliber football players than those that can be police/firemen. Part of their pay is in fact due to their elite skill status - AND they make the owners far more money than they earn. So they are not an expense, they are a high valued commodity. They can make in the hundreds of thousands or millions because their performance on the field yields billions for the owners. A novelist like GRRM isn't comparable to some crappy blogger because of his talent level and the money he makes for his publishers. He is paid accordingly.
Problem is, the Packers are publicly owned ;)  But I agree in spirit!

Whenever I hear about unions, a part of me gets really sad, and another part wants to start drinking heavily.

I studied unions at university, looking at the rhetoric of worker's rights movements (awith the "typical" social movements everyone knows about, civil rights, etc.).

I'm not a historian by any stretch of the word, but my issue with unions is this- haven't they already won? Haven't workers got what they strove (and legitimately suffered) for? Labor laws now work on behalf of the individual (as all rights laws are meant to, according to the Constitution).

So why are union leaders still addressing the system like it's the 1800s? Maybe I'm naive (hell, I'm still young!) because I don't have a union to "represent" me, but I don't see the point of the structure of the union anymore. This is America- if you feel wronged, you take your issue to the party that wronged you. If one person is wronging many people, then the odds are stacked against them in both the courtroom and the office.

The concept of unions worries me because politics in itself is a rotten deal, and the union figure in itself is just compounding those politics. I can't help but be suspicious of people who keep rehashing the same grievances despite fulfilling their goals. :<

A friend of mine that works for an American multinational in Ireland recently made pretty much exactly the same argument. Representation and organisation is why. Just because a law or a right is there doesn't mean it is automatically available, sometimes it needs to be fought for.

Within a week of her making that comment, the Labour Court here made judgements in two separate disputes:

#1 The Davenport Hotel dispute. Here, the employers said to the domestic staff, essentially "Even though you don't speak English well, or at all, you must sign this new contract that reduces your wages and other conditions, right now, in this room, without benefit of a translator, or a union rep, or be taken off the payroll. You may not take away the new contract to get advice or have it translated."

#2 Aer Lingus (Ireland's national airline). Here, they said to the stewards "We're just unilaterally changing your rosters, so that you have no idea from day to day when you'll be working. This may have the effect of making childcare arrangements literally impossible, but the side-effect of forcing people with children (therefore, demographically, likely to be older and therefore more senior/better paid) to resign is *completely* coincidental."

It took union action in both cases to preserve workers rights, using industrial action to even get the employers to agree to use the Labour Court mechanism.

And sometimes, as in Wisconsin, somebody tries to take your rights away anyway.

comments.subject: While I see what your getting at...

comments.article:
If I were king -- with dragons to enforce my will -- or if the NFL players and owners came to me to arbitrate the dispute, and ceded me all power and authority, I would decree:
-- the players get less money. The league minimums all remain the same, but we bring in a rookie salary scale, and shave some off the obscene amounts being made by the biggest names,
-- the owners get less money. All books have to be opened, so we know how much truth there is to the claims that some teams are losing money. Every franchise playing in a stadium built in whole or in part with taxpayer money must cede partial ownership of that franchise to the muncipality that built the stadium. We need more public ownership, like Green Bay. Even minority ownership would be a good start.
-- some of the money we took away from the millionaire players and billionaire owners, we give to the retired players, the guys who built this league, many of whom are struggling with health problems on inadequate pensions.
-- the rest of the money we took away from the millionaire players and billionaire owners, we give back to the FANS in the form of lower ticket prices. We start by abolishing the obscenity called Personal Seat Licenses.

That would be a great start. I would be hailed as Savior of the League and Father of the Fans.

Sigh. It is all a pipe dream. I have no dragons.

But... hey... maybe soon....
comments.subject: How I'd Settle the Dispute

comments.article:
I'm with you expect for two aspects, one being the minimums. Guys who give it their all to manage just a couple years in the league generally are there by effort over natural talent. That tends to also mean special teams involvement, which inevitably will be shown to have a high correlation with concussions. Until the owners put their health at risk, let the little guy players get a decent cushion for their post football careers.

Now, I agree they should have open finances, open to all the public (I wonder if it could be made public as a requisite for anti-trust status, for all sports, heck, for all anti-trust exempts!).

But my second thought is that the owners should also be on the hook for the medical treatment costs and disabilities which result in their farm system, the NCAA. Anyone who remains in good academic standing while playing would be eligible (resulting in the likelihood that the NFL would actually police bogus eligibility of players).

While bummed, a shorter preseason will give you a bit more time for writing.
comments.subject: Re: How I'd Settle the Dispute
Re: How I'd Settle the Dispute

comments.article: AMEN! My wife (HS english teacher who enjoys your books as well as I) just said: GRRM is my new hero.

I see some other people who are smarter than me have made this point but it bears repeating. This situation is the fault of the owners. This in no way makes the players unselfish or good people, its just in this particular fight the owners are the instigators. I do find it distasteful to pick sides in a fight between millionaires and billionaires, but in this case its easy. The NFL is by far the most popular and profitable sport in the country and the owners are the ones claiming to be poor. Lets see them open their books.
comments.subject: This debacle is more the owners fault.

comments.article: I am one of those "radical right" (big Ron Paul supporter actually).  I have no problem with teachers, police and firefighters making as much as they can.  But I completely disagree with the concept of public unions and collective bargaining.  What you have there is a situation where the people paying the bill (the taxpayers) are not at the table.  The politicians deal with the unions, and you get the whole "You scratch my back I'll scratch yours" thing going on.  The politicians agree to things, and the unions donate to help them get re-elected.  You are naive to think that this doesn't happen.
comments.subject: You are wrong about the Wisconsin issue

comments.article:
The politicians represent the taxpayers. The taxpayers elect them for that very purpose.

When a corporation negotiates a deal with its employees, the "people paying the bill" -- the shareholders -- are not at the table either. They are represented by the board of directors, the people they elected.

You would need a very big table to do it your way.
